title: Visualizing sloWNet

author: Darja Fišer, Faculty of Arts, University of Ljubljana

segmentation: Hi, my name is Eddie Fisher.
I'm from the University of Ljubljana an I'm going to be talking about the visualization of slow net.
This is an outline of my presentation.
First I will say a few words or on what Sloan it is.
Then I will try to explain why.
I am doing this presentation on the in the 1st place.
Then I will present the tool that we developed for visual visualization of slow net and then I'll conclude the presentation and give some ideas of possible future work.
Slow net is a word net for Slovene which I developed for my PhD.
It's based on Princeton Wordnet, the structure of word Net was preserved as it is in Princeton Wordnet.
And it is sort of semantic lexicon.
It differs from traditional dictionaries in the way that words, nouns, adjectives, verbs and adverbs are grouped into sets of synonyms, each representing distinct concept.
Then these scene sets are linked between each other into a network, a semantic network with a set of semantic and lexical relations.
Currently, Princeton Wordnet contains more than 100,000 synsets, an more than 150,000 unique literals.
Slovene Wordnet was not developed manually as Princeton Wordnet was, for obvious reasons.
We didn't have enough resources resources, it was more or less A1.
One man job or a one woman job, so to speak.
I developed it automatically from various existing language resources, mostly from bilingual dictionaries from parallel corpus and from Wikipedia articles.
A small part of the developed world net was manually revised, but not all of it, so it is still noisy.
It still contains some errors and ever since it was developed it was already used for semantic annotation of the 100K corpus.

So currently we have the third version of slow Net, which is still quite smaller compared to the Princeton Word Net, but we currently have 43,000 synsets, which means that in these, since it's there, about 40,000 unique literals because they are polysemous, they amount to 82,000 since in literal pairs average length of a, since it in slow net.

Is 1.9 two which means that they are almost in every sense that there are two words average polysemy of words included in slow net currently is slightly more than two, which means that the same word appears on average in two different senses.
Now, why do we want to visualize slow net?

Well, my at the end of my PhD, my supervisors my The people who financed my research, my parents and my students were all interested in the resource that was developed, but because we're not is a different kind of resource, I could not use the typical.
In systems that traditional dictionaries used to represent the information an I could not use the resources and tools that are used for ontology maintenance.
Becausw semantic lexicons are specific, and even though there are some tools that already exist to display word net information, I was not really happy with using one particular already existing.
Tool and This is why we decided to come up with our own tool.
The tools that are currently available.
There's several I'm just mentioning here.
The most well known ones for the Princeton Wordnet, the Princeton Word.
Net browser was developed.

The problem that I had with this browser is that it's either only available as a desktop application or only as an online application, but it does not allow editing, so users cannot correct mistakes if they find them in slow net.
There have been two editors developed within the euro Word Net project which allow for multilingual setting and they also allow for editing, but they're not really available.
And in the Balconette project, David Stick was used and this was the editor editor that we started using as soon as slow net was developed.
But even though it allows multilingual research scenarios and it allows editing of automatically created where net it's not very user friendly.
If you want too a lot of people to correct.
The the word net.
They you first need to give them usernames and passwords.

They cannot register by themselves and they need to download a special client in Fire Fox and anytime Firefoxes updated they are somewhat behind and then the visit doesn't work for some time and it's quite frustrating.
So when we were thinking about what to do to display the information that's now available in slow net, we invent, Envision envisaged an ideal tool.
We want it to be freely available just as any other component in our project.
We want it to be platform independent and an online application because people will be accessing the tool from anywhere.
We also don't want to use separate tools for.
Individual tasks if you want to browse your word net or to edit it, you don't want to be using two different tools.

Also, we wanted to incorporate visualization in a graph like way, so we wanted to add everything to the same tool we wanted to support the standardized format so that other people see if they want to use the tool.
Don't have a problem with trying to comply with your in-house data format.
We want we definitely need support for multi lingual research scenarios.

We want to be able to compare how a concept is lexicalized in several languages, and we also want the tool to be to be easy to handle when we want to integrate some resources that were developed by somebody else, such as word domain hierarchy.
We have tried to incorporate coarse grained sense clusters that were developed by Retina Valley.
And the image net library library of images that are linked with word net sense.
Is.

To conclude this presentation, I think there are three basic advantages of the tool that we developed.
It's an all-in-one browser, so you don't need separate tools for separate tasks.
You can search.
You can edit the word net and you can visualize the network that gets created.
You don't have to work only with slow net.
In this tool, you can import all other word Nets.
The only condition is that they need to follow.
They need to have the Princeton word net IDs.
But if you don't need the word Nets to be interlinked and using parallel, you can also use the same tool for any other lexical database as well.
You can use it for simple searches.
You can adapt the view settings so if you're not interested in the semantic relations, you can just turn them off if not interested in the usage examples, you just turn them off.
If you're not interested in the definitions, you can just turn them off.
You can also turn on and off the various languages that are imported.
We've even gone a step further by integrating some external resources such as the example sentences from the manually annotated corpus.
The word net domain hierarchy so that now you can use you can look for all the sensors for all the synsets in bookkeeping or the financial domain.
We have also started using the coarse grained sense clusters, so if you're not only interested in the very fine grained.
Word Nets sends distinctions.

If you want to use the tool for browsing, you can just click on this link here and just use it for Slovene or English.

My SQL and PHP.

About the named entities in right now.
